item.title: PSFK Future of Work Report 2013
item.description: As part of our popular series of ’Future of’ reports, we release today a 140 page document that covers the new ways we are working and the implications for business and for workers. Available in different formats to buy or just preview, the themes of PSFK’s Future of Work report cover the Ideal Workforce, Empowered Culture, Intuitive Connection and Agile Workplaces. Within each theme we describe 4 trends and each trend is supported by 4 examples, supporting statistics and implications defined by our PSFK Labs team. During this process we spoke to a number of experts to understand the trends better. Their feedback can be found in quotes and interviews throughout the report. As a bonus, we also turned to a number of creative agencies to bring the trends to life. We asked them to imagine the future of work and you will find their concepts within this document. At the end of the report, you will also discover the submission of examples of progressive work environments. These were submitted by the readers of PSFK.com after we asked for their input into the report in 2012. We hope that you find inspiration in every section of PSFK’s Future of Work report. For copies, downloads or an in-person presentation please visit: http://bit.ly/VghG9z

item.title: A digital strategy for Lindsay Lohan
item.description: What would you say is the most challenging brand in 2013? From Disney Princess, to nightclub brawling, Playboy revealing train-wreck...welcome to brand Lindsay Lohan. The brand equity in Lindsay is at an all time low, and she desperately needs to regain some public respect in order to get back to the job of show biz. So can we use digital, a platform that nearly crucified her career, to help Lindsay turn it around?
item.content:encoded: What would you say is the most challenging brand in 2013? From Disney Princess, to nightclub brawling, Playboy revealing train-wreck...welcome to brand Lindsay Lohan. The brand equity in Lindsay is at an all time low, and she desperately needs to regain some public respect in order to get back to the job of show biz. So can we use digital, a platform that nearly crucified her career, to help Lindsay turn it around?

item.title: 50 Things to Give Up

item.title: Startup Growth and Traction: How to get users to contribute on your platform
item.description: More details at http://platformed.info User contribution hacking. A presentation I gave recently on incentivizing user contributions. This details the elements required to set up and maximize user contributions on platforms like YouTube, Flickr, Dribbble etc.

item.title: 5 BIG tips to Become a Presentation Jedi - @itseugenec
item.description: My first self-initiated slide-deck outlining some ways to build better presentations through visuals and delivery. Presentation includes links to external sites that act as resources when building a presentation. Become a #PresentationJedi today! ( Even if you’re a non-Starwars Fan, you’ll get it ) Many thanks to J.D.Hancock for his awe-inspiring photos ( @JDHancock ) and the many presentation gurus for their inspirational slide-decks. -Download is available with just a Tweet! @ http://goo.gl/wGYTZ P.S. a little long but i’ll re-upload a condensed version *No Copyright Infringement Intended. Images used under the Creative Commons License by @JDHancock . I love Star Wars.

item.title: Tips for Delivering an Elevator Pitch
item.description: The elevator door opens. And there stands your ideal investor. It’s the chance of a lifetime. But that chance only lasts as long as the elevator ride - you have less than a minute to make an impression. Hopefully, you’ve got a well-crafted elevator pitch ready to give. The elevator pitch is not the hurried presentation of a full-blown business plan. It’s an introduction, an overview and a pitch - and a short one at that - meant to capture the attention of a potential investor. Of course, an elevator ride is a short one. Guides for elevator speeches that say you have one minute surely overestimate the amount of time it takes for an elevator to move from floor to floor. Of course, an elevator speech isn’t restricted to elevators. Rather, it comes in handy for any occasion where a concise presentation is appropriate. When crafting your pitch there are two key things to keep in mind: its content and its form. In other words, it’s not just what you say but how you say it. Here are a 10 tips to keep in mind as you craft and deliver your elevator pitch.

But that chance only lasts as long as the elevator ride - you have less than a minute to make an impression. Hopefully, you’ve got a well-crafted elevator pitch ready to give. The elevator pitch is not the hurried presentation of a full-blown business plan. It’s an introduction, an overview and a pitch - and a short one at that - meant to capture the attention of a potential investor. Of course, an elevator ride is a short one. Guides for elevator speeches that say you have one minute surely overestimate the amount of time it takes for an elevator to move from floor to floor. Of course, an elevator speech isn’t restricted to elevators. Rather, it comes in handy for any occasion where a concise presentation is appropriate. When crafting your pitch there are two key things to keep in mind: its content and its form. In other words, it’s not just what you say but how you say it. Here are a 10 tips to keep in mind as you craft and deliver your elevator pitch.
item.author: abhishekshah@slideshare.net(abhishekshah)

When crafting your pitch there are two key things to keep in mind: its content and its form. In other words, it’s not just what you say but how you say it. Here are a 10 tips to keep in mind as you craft and deliver your elevator pitch.
